titlestmt.title: SSSC 34: The Foolish Maidens and One-Leg
titlestmt.author: Coming-Day

bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

body.head: Sacred Stories 34: The Foolish Maidens and One-Leg

p.seg: mîkiwahpis êh-ayâcik , êh-nîsicik , pisisik êh-papâmohtêcik , êh-ntonahkik ka-mîcicik , nama wîhkâc ayîsiyiniwa wâpamêwak . The two had a small tipi, and all the time they walked about, looking for things to eat, and never saw any people.
nôhtê-wâpamêwak ayîsiyinwa . They wished to see people.

mâskôc nâpêw wâpamâyahkih , ka-wîkimânaw , ka-mîciyahk ta-nipahtât , itwêw aw ômisimâw ; “If by any chance we see a man, we shall marry him, that he may kill things for us to eat,” said the elder sister;

seg.gloss: “Do not then reject him.

p.seg: kiyâm pikw îsi mâyâtisici nâpêw ka-wîkimânaw , itwêw aw ômisimâw . Rather let us marry a man, no matter how ugly,” said the elder sister.
êhag , osîma . “Yes,” said the younger.
êkwah êkotah ay-ayâwak pêyakwanaw . There they stayed on. CHECK pêyakwanaw

kîtahtawê , êh-tipiskâyik , êh-wîh-nipâcik , êh-kitâpamât aw ômisimâw acâhkosah , pêyak kîhkânâkosiyiwa ; pêyak apisîsisiyiwa ; namoya kîhkânâkosiw . Then at one time, after dark, as they were about to sleep, when the elder sister looked at the stars, one looked bright, and another was small and did not shine brightly.

ômisih itwêw aw ômisimâw :
hê êy , nisîmis , tânik ôki onâpêmiyahk , tâniki nêki acâhkosak ! Thus spoke the elder sister: “Oh, little sister, would we might have them for husbands, yon stars!
nâha kâ-kîhkânâkosit êwakô niy ônâpêmiyân , êkwa kiya ana k-âpisîsisit , itêw . Would I might have as husband that one that shines so brightly, and you the smaller one,” she said to the other.
êhag , itik . “Yes,” answered she.

êkos êh-itêyihtahk :
êh-miyosit awa kâ-kîhkânâkosit , êh-itêyihtahk . What she thought was, “The one that shines brightly is handsome.”
êkos îsi nipâwak . [no translation]
kîksêpâ êh-pêkopayit aw ômisimâw , kâ-kiskêyimât nâpêwa ê-pimisiniyit . [no translation]

êh-mâmîskonât ,
nâpêw ! itêyihtam . [no translation] CHECK mâmîskonât
waniskâw , êh-kotawêt . She got up and built the fire.
nisîmis , waniskâh ! itêw . “Little sister, get up!” she called to her.
wâpamêw mîna êkotê êh-nipâyit nâpêwa . [no translation]
awa êh-waniskât osîmimâw , miywêyihtam nâpêwa êh-pimisiniyit . [no translation]

aw ômisimâw itwahamawêw osîmisah owîkimâkana ôhi , tahkih ê-wîh-pâhpit , êh-miywêyihtahk nâpêwa êh-ayâwât . The elder sister pointed out her husband to the younger, smiling all the while with gladness at having a husband.
êkos êh-kîsitêpot , mînisah pikoh êh-mîcicik . Then she cooked; they had only berries to eat.
êkosi waniskâw aw ôsîmimâw owîkimâkana : pôtih miyosiw oskinîkiw . Then the younger sister's husband got up: he turned out to be a handsome young man.
âh , miywêyihtam awa aw îskwêw . Oh, she was glad, that woman.

mwêstas ka-waniskâyit aw ômisimâw owîkimâkana , pôt ôhi mitoni kisêyiniwa , ê-wâpistikwânêyit . Then, after a bit, when the elder one's husband got up, he turned out to be a very old man with white hair.
pakwâtam ê-kisêyiniwiyit . She did not like his being old.
êkosi êkotah ay-ayâwak . So then they stayed there.
kapê-kîsik ay-apiyiwa . The men sat there all day.
êyikohk ê-tipiskâyik , aspin wâh-wayawiyiwa . Only at nightfall they left the house and went away.
êyikohk kêkâc êh-wâpaniyik , kâ-takohtêyit . When daybreak was near, they came back.
êkosi êh-kawisimoyit . Then they went to bed.

kîksêpâ mâna kâh-mîcisotwâwi , êh-papâmohtêcik osîma , mînisah êh-ntonahkik , mîna mistaskosîmina , êkotôwah piko êh-mîcicik , nama wîhkâc mâciyiwa ôwîkimâkaniwâwa . In the morning, when they had eaten, the elder sister and the younger would always go tramping about, looking for berries and for wild turnips, for these were all they had to eat; but never did their husbands hunt.
kîtahtawê kinwêsk êh-ayâcik , kîtahtawê namoya nisitawinam askiy aw ômisimâw . Then at one time, when they had been there quite a while, the elder sister did not recognize the land.
tâpiskôc êkâ wîhkâc êh-wâpahtahk askiy itêyihtam . It seemed to her as if she had never seen the land where they were.
kaskêyihtam , pîhtaw êh-pakwâtahk kisêyiniwa êh-onâpêmit . She was sad, and she disliked having for husband, as it turned out, an old man.
piyisk pisisik papâmohtêw . Then she kept wandering about.
êkwah kaskêyihtam nam âwiya êkotah kâ-kîh-ayâcik ; êyokô ohci k-ôh-kaskêyihtahk . And she was sad because there were no other people there where they dwelt; this it was made her sad.

kîtahtawê mâka mîna êh-papâmohtêcik , mistaskosîmina êh-papâh-mônahahkik , kâ-wâpahtahk wistêpahkwayikamik . Then at one time, when as usual they were wandering about, digging wild turnips here and there, they saw a lodge of old leather.
nisîmis , êkwah kiyôkêtân ! itêw . “Little sister, now let us visit!” she said to her.
tâpwê êh-itohtêcik , êh-takohtêcik , awan ôhi , nôtokêsiwa . When, accordingly, they went there, when they arrived, there was an old woman.
nôsisimak , nôsisimak ! itwêyiwa . “My grandchildren, my grandchildren!” she said.
pîhtokêwak . They went in.
asamêwak mistaskosîmina . They gave her wild turnips to eat.

seg.gloss: “Dear me, you really please me much, my grandchildren!

seg.q:
kayâs nôh-akâwâtên , êh-pêhtamân ê-kih-pêsîkawiyêk ,
mistaskosîminah êh-otinahkik tahkih , êh-itikawiyêk .
seg.gloss: For a long while I have been hankering for these, ever since I heard that you were brought here, you of whom they say, “They are always getting wild turnips.'”

p.seg: nôhkô , ê-kîh-cî-pêsîkawiyâhk ? itêw . “Grandmother, is it true, that we have been brought here?” she asked her.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg: namoya , nôsisê ! ispimihk ôma êh-ayâyêk , ôtê nîhcâyihk ê-kiy-ohtohtahikawiyêk , itik ; “By no means, my grandchild! It is up aloft that you are, and from yon place below that you were conveyed,” she told her;

seg.gloss: “Grandchild, do you think, ‘They are mortal men whom we have as husbands’?”
seg.note: LB on {cî}: The interrogative particle comes near the beginning of the sentence, usually after the first word; here it is inserted in a quotation of which it does not form a part. Compare its insertion in the verbal complex immediately below.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”
“Not they.
When you of mortal race say, ‘Stars.’ of that kind is he.

seg.q:
nama cî ,
anah kâ-kîhkâyâsôwêt êwako onâpêmiyân , kikîh-itwân ? êwakôw ana kônâpêmin kisêyiniw .
seg.gloss: Did you not say, ‘The one that shines bright let me have for my husband’? That old man you now have for your husband.

seg.q:
êkwah ,
ana êkâ kâ-taspâsôwêt êyakoni onâpêmiyin , kikîh-itâw kisîm ;
seg.gloss: and, ‘That one that does not shine so clear may you have for your husband,’ you said of your younger sister;

p.seg: êyakô ohci anih ôskinîkiwa kâ-wîcêwât , itêw . that is why she has that youth for her mate,” she told her.

seg.gloss: “Alas, grandmother, can you help us to get back home?

p.seg: nipîkiskâtênân nitaskînân , itêw . We are pining for our earth,” she told her.
hâhag , nôsisê ; ayisk kikâkêpâtisin , êh-kîh-nôhtêh-onâpêmiyin acâhkos , itik ; “Yes, my grandchild, but indeed you were foolish to want a star for your husband,” she told her;

seg.gloss: “Well then, grandchild, look for a wild turnip.

seg.q: mostoso-mêy itah êh-astêk , êkotah sâkikihkih mistaskosîmin , êwakô kik-ôhpinên .
seg.gloss: The wild turnip which grows out from where the buffalo dung lies, that one you will pull up.

p.seg: êkotah anima ê-pakonêyâk ôm askiy , itik ; That is where this land is pierced,” she told her:

seg.gloss: “When you find it, come and tell me.”
“Yes.”

p.seg: wayawîwak , êh-ntonahkik . They went out of the lodge and looked for it.
kiyipa miskamwak . They soon found it.
êkosi ntawi-wîhtamawêwak ôhkomiwâwa . So then they went and told their grandmother.
nimiskênân , itêw . “We have found it,” she told her.
êkosi otinamiyiwa osêkipatwânêyâpîsiyiw . Then she took the little thong with which her braid was tied.

seg.gloss: “Now then, tie this to a tree.
By means of this you will get away and reach your destination.
Make a nest in which you will sit.
When you have finished it, and are ready to descend, you yourself will wrap your head.
You will not look about to see things until you reach your earth.
Only your younger sister here will look.

p.seg:
êkwah nêtê takosiniyêko ,
nôhkô , êwakwê kisêkipatwânêyâpiy ! kik-êtwân , nôsisê , itêw ; Then, when you arrive down there, ‘Grandmother, here is the thong of your braid!’ you will call, my grandchild,” she told them;

seg.gloss: “Well then, be off!”

p.seg: wayawîwak , êh-itohtêcik ôm îtah kâ-pakwanêyâk askiy , êkwah êy-osîhtâcik wacistwan . They went out of the lodge to the place where the land was pierced, and made the nest.

ê-kîsihtâcik , êkwah mistikohk tahkopitamwak oma pîsâkanâpis , êkwah êh-pôsicik wacistwanihk , êkwah ê-nîhtakosîcik , êh-pakitâpîhkênisocik . When they had finished it, they tied it to a tree with that little rawhide thong, and got into the nest, and descended, letting themselves down on the string.
wêwêkistikwânêw awa omisimâw , êh-nîhtakocihkik . The elder sister wrapped up her head as they swung down.

kîtahtawê ,
nisîmis , tânêhki ? namêskwa cîh kitaskiyinaw kiwâpahtên ? Presently, “Little sister, how is it? Do you not yet see our earth?”
êhag ! nama cêskwah ! itêw . “No! Not yet!” she told her.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk . Presently she saw it.

êkwah aw ôskinîkiskwêw ,
nisîmis , namâ cêskwa kiwâpahtên ? Then that young woman, “Little sister, do you not yet see it?”

seg.gloss: “Yes, now I do,”

seg.q: hây hây ! êkwah ê-wîh-takosiniyahk kitaskiyinaw , nisîmis !
seg.gloss: “Splendid! Now we shall come back to our earth, little sister!
Do let me look!”

p.seg: êkâ wiya ! kikîh-itikonaw kôhkominaw , ‘iyikohk kitaskiyiwâw takohtêyêko , kik-êtâpin ,’ ê-kîh-itisk , itêw omisah . “Don't! Our grandmother told us, ‘Only when you have reached your earth will you look,’ she told you,” said she to her elder sister.
tahkih êh-yâsipayicik , tahkih kakwêcimêw osîma taskiyiwâw . All the time they were going down she kept questioning her younger sister about their earth.
kêkâc êkwah ! miton êkwah kîhkânâkosiwak mistikwak , itêw . “We are almost there now! The trees appear plainly now,” she told her.
nisîmis , mahti nik-êtâpin ! itêw . “Little sister, do let me look!” she asked her.

êh- ,
êkâ wiyah ! kisiwâk êkwah ! êh-itikot osîmisah , âhci pikoh wîh-kakwê-itâpiw . “Do not! We are near now!” her younger sister told her, but still she longed to take a look. LB on {êh-}: Start toward including quotation in verbal complex.
âtah ê-wêwêkistikwânênikot osîma , kîtahtawê pâskipayikôw , êh-itâpit . Although her younger sister held the covering round her head, suddenly she threw off the cover and looked.
paskipayiyiw ôma k-ô-sakâhpisocik . The string broke by which they were tied.
nîhcipayiwak êkwah êh-kinosiyit mistikwah , êkotah akotâskociniyiw ôma wacistwan . Down they went. The nest caught on a tall tree and hung there.

tâpwê kikakêpâtisin , nimisê , ê-kîh-itikoyahk kôhkominaw êkâ kâ-tâpwêhtaman ! itêw ômisah . “Really, you are foolish, big sister, not to heed what our grandmother told us!” she said to her elder sister.
hâh , miywêyihtamwak otaskiyiwâw êh-wâpahtahkik . Oh, they were glad to see their earth.
mâka namoya kîh-pihkohôwak ; êkotê ay-akosîwak . But they could not get there; they hung there aloft.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamâcik êh-pâpahtâyit mahîhkanah . Presently they saw a wolf who was running that way.
hêy , nisîmis , nka-wayêsimâw mahîhkan ; ka-pihkohikonaw , itêw . “Oh, little sister, I shall fool the wolf; he will get us down,” she said to the other.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg:
â , kisiwâk êh-pimohtêyit , ômis îtêw :
mahîhkan ! êh-kitâpamikot ,
pihkohinân ! When he came near, she said to him, “Wolf!” and when he looked at her, “Get us down.

seg.gloss: Take us down from where we are caught.
We are even willing to marry you, if you like.”
“Yoho! I am not a good climber.
Also, you would be a bother to me;

p.seg: ma wîhkâc pêyakwanohk ntayân , pisisik êh-papâmâcihoyân , itwêyiwa . I never stay in one place, but travel about all the time,” said he.

sêsêy ! misawâ cî tapwê ka-kîh-wîkimitanân , êh-mâyâtisiyan , êh-kinwâpêkihkwêyan , êkwah êh-kâsakêyan , kêkway nêpahtâyanih êh-pêyakôhkaman ! itêw , êh-kîhkâmât . “Faugh! Do you suppose we would really marry you, ugly as you are, and long-faced, and a glutton, who, whenever you kill anything, eat it all by yourself?” she told him, reviling him.
êkosih ay-ayâwak êkotah . And so they stayed there.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamâcik mînah kotakah êh-pâpahtâyit . Presently they saw another who came running that way.
pôtih êwakonih pisiwah . He turned out to be a lynx.

seg.q: hê êy , nisîmis , êyakow êkwah ka-wayêsimânaw !
seg.gloss: “Oh, little sister, let us fool this one!
The like of him are good climbers.

p.seg:
- hêh ! ôtah êh-pimohtêyit ,
hê ê êy , pisiw ! Hey there!” as he walked by, “Hey, hey, lynx!”

seg.gloss: “What is it?”

seg.q: pihkohinân ! ahpôh ici ka-wîkimitinân , êkâ êh-kêh-nihtinisoyâhk !
seg.gloss: “Get us down from here! We will even marry you, if you like; we cannot get down!”
“Yoho! I am not a good climber.

p.seg: îh wâpahtah nicihciyah : nama kêkway naskasiyak , itwêyiwa . Look here at my paws: I haven't any nails,” said he.

seg.q: ê ê êy , misawâ cî tâpwê ka-kîh-wîkimitâhk , êh-mâyâtisiyan , êh-pitikohkwêyin , êkwah êh-mâmâhkisitêyin , êkw ê-nâ-napakâskitoyêyin ?
seg.gloss: “Ho ho, do you suppose we would marry you in any case, you ugly fellow, with your crumpled-up snout and your big feet and your flat rump?”

p.seg: ay-âtawêyimêw . She gave up the chances of him.
êkosi nakatikok . So he left them.
â , kaskêyihtamwak , ê-nôhtê-nihtakosîcik . Oh, they were sad, because they wanted to get down to earth.
piyisk kinwêsk êkotah ayâwak . Finally they had been there a long time.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamâcik mîna êh-pâpahtâyit . Presently they saw still another come running that way.

seg.gloss: “Little sister, now I shall cheat this one.

p.seg: wîh-wawîwinawisiw êwako , itêw . This one will be eager to take wives,” she said to the other. LB on {wîh-wawîwinawisiw}: Obscure; perhaps a nonce-formation. If really derived from {wîwah}: “his wife” ({nîwah}: “my wife,” etc.), perhaps read {wîh-owîwinawisiw}; for the general rule in Central Algonquian is that secondary derivatives of dependent nouns are made from the form with third-person possessor; those in {nî-, kî-, wî-} prefix {o-}, e.g., {wîstâwah}: “his brother-in-law”: {uwîstâwiw}: “he has (as) a brother-in-law”; and those in {nô-}, {kô-}, {ô-} prefix {ow-}, e.g. {ôhtâwiya}: “his father”: {owôhtâwiyiw}: “he has (as) a father.” But the Sweet Grass dialect seems to confuse this initial accretion with reduplication, e.g. {oyôhtâwiyiw}: “he has (as) a father,” cf. below.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg:
kisiwâk ê-pimipayiyit ôtah ,
hê êy ! As he came running close by there, “Hey, hey!”
itâpiyiwa . He looked up.

seg.gloss: “Wolverine, you are a good climber.
Get us down from here.
We are frightened and do not know how to get down.

p.seg: ahpôh ici , pihkohiyâhkoh , ka-wîkimitinân , itâw . We are even willing, if you rescue us, to marry you,” she told him.
yahô , kiwîh-wayêsiminâwâw ! itwêyiwa . “Hoho, you mean to fool me!” said he.
namoya ! tâpwê ka-wîkimitinân , itêw . “No! Really, we will marry you,” she told him.

seg.gloss: “Very well then!”

p.seg: haw , pê-kihcêkosiyiwa . So he came climbing up.

êy-otihtikocik ,
niya nîkân ! itwêw aw ômisimâw . When he had reached them, “Me first!” said the elder sister.

seg.gloss: “No! Wait; first comes your sister.”
“Very well.”

p.seg: êkwah nayômêw êkwah . Then he took her on his back.

seg.q: hâw , êkâ wiyah moscih sâmiskaw nitakohp .
seg.gloss: “Now then, do not rub yourself directly against my robe.

p.seg: mitoni nikihcêyimâw nitakohp , itêw ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa . I think a great deal of my robe,” he told the young woman.
mitoni wêwêkîw aw ôskinîkiskwêw , êh-nîhcaciwêhtahikot . The young woman wrapped herself very carefully in her clothes, and he climbed down with her.
piyis pihkohêw . At last he had got her down.

pitah ômis îsi tah-tihtipîw awa kîhkwahâkês , ôhô otakohpah êh-kâsîsimât , ôh îskwêwa ê-sâmiskawâyit . Then, before doing any more, the wolverine rolled himself over and over, like this, to wipe his robe clean where the woman had come into contact with it.

âsay êkosi itêyihtam nah ômisimâw :
nihtinicih , nika-yîpâcihimâwa otakohpah , kâ-kistêyimot ! itêyimêw . Then that elder sister thought, “When he takes me down, I will dirty up his robe, the conceited fellow!” she thought of him.
êkwah pêy-âmaciwêyiwa mîna . Then he came up again.

êy-otihtikot ,
hâw , mitonih wêwêkapih . When he had reached her, “Now then, sit carefully wrapped in your clothes.
nitakohp nikihcêyimâw , itêyiwa . I think very highly of my robe,” he said.
êkwah nayômik . Then he took her on his back.

êkwah êh-nihcaciwêyâhtawiyit , pêyâhtik êh-pimohtêyit ,
kisiskâhtê , kîhkwahâkis ! nikaskêyihtên , êh-nôhtê-sâmiskamân ntaskiy , itwêw aw iskwêw . And as he climbed down, because he went slowly and carefully, “Hurry up, wolverine! I am miserable with longing to set foot on my earth,” said the woman.
âhci pikoh pêyâhtik êh-pimohtêyit , waniskâpayihôw aw îskwêw , êh-kâhkapê-têhtapit . [no translation]
ôhi kîhkwahâkêsah ê-sikitât . [no translation]
kwêtipipayihoyiwa , êh-nîhcipayihoyit . He rolled over and flung himself down to the ground.

seg.gloss: “It is horrible, what you are doing to my robe!

p.seg: nikatawatêyimâh nitakohp ! itwêyiwa . Did I not tell you that I valued my handsome robe!” he cried.
êkwah aw îskwêw kâ-nîhcipayit , ohcikwanihk kaskatêsin . As the woman fell, she broke her leg just above the knee.

êh-ati-sipwêhtêyit kîhkwahâkêsah , aw ômis îtwêw oskinîkiskwêw :
hê êy , kîhkwahâkês , iyikohk kâ-wîsakisimiyin , ntawâc anim îtah kâ-sikitak kitakohp kâkikê êkotah ta-masinasôw , isko tit-âskîwik ! itêw ; As the wolverine started to go away, the young woman said to him, “Oho, wolverine, since you have thus given me a painful fall, let your robe needs forever be marked there [no translation] as long as there be, an earth!” she said to him;

seg.q: mîna cêskwa ayîsiyiniwak kâ-wîh-ohpikicik , nama wîhkâc kika-môwikwak ;
seg.gloss: “And later, when mortal men grow into life, never shall they eat you;
[no translation]
‘Wolverine,’ they will call you.

p.seg: êkosi sipwêhtêyiwa . Then he went away.
hâ , nisîmis , itah mihtah êh-mihcêkih itohtahin , itêw . “Oh, little sister, take me where there is plenty of firewood,” she said to the other.

â , tâpwê otakohpihk êkwah otâpâtik osîma , itah mihtah êh-mihcêniyikih , êkotah ê-takohtayikot . So then her sister dragged her on her blanket-robe, taking her to a place where there was plenty of firewood.

êkwah osîhtâw wîkiwâw nîpiyah ohci oma wîkiwâw , êkwah aw ôskinîkiskwêw pisisik êh-nikohtêt , êh-pônamawât omisa , ê-wîsakêyihtamiyit ôm ôskâtiyiw , êkâ mwâsi êh-nipâyit , êh-wâh-wâpaniyik êh-pônahk . Then she made a lodge for them out of leaves, and then all the time the young woman gathered firewood, to keep up a fire for her sister, who was suffering from her leg and sleeping hardly at all; every morning she built a fire.
piyisk kinwês wîsakêyihtam ; namoya kîh-îniyiw . At last she had been sick a long time; her wound would not heal.

kîtahtawê osîma êh-nikohtêyit , otinam môhkomân , êh-kîskisahk ôm ôskât itah kânâtwâhtiniyik . Then at one time, while her younger sister was gathering firewood, she took a knife and cut off her leg there where it was broken.
êkwah mistahi sâkamoyiw ôma oskan . The bone stuck far out.
êkwah êwakô cîkaham môhkomân ohci , êh-aciwikahahk . She whittled it with the knife, shaping it off small.
êh-kîwêt aw ôskinîkiskwêw , kâ-pêhtahk êh-matwê-cîkahikêyit omisah . When the young woman was coming home, she heard the sound of her elder sister chopping away at something.
cîk êh-ihtât , pônihtâyiwa , êh-akwanahamiyit , êh-kâtâyit . When she got near, the other stopped her work and covered it with her robe, to hide it.
namoya wâpahtam êh-tôtamiyit omisah . She could not see what her elder sister had been doing.

ômis êh-itêyihtahk aw ômisimâw :
nisîmis nika-wîwin , êh-itêyihtahk ,
ômôw ohci niskât , êh-itêyihtahk . But what the elder sister thought was this: “[no translation]” she thought.

êh , kîtahtawê êh-nâh-nikohtêyit mâna aw ôskinîkiskwêw , kîtahtawê môyêyimêw omisah , kâkikê êh-kitâpamikot , tahkih ê-wîh-pâhpihikot . Then presently, as the young woman continued to gather faggots, presently she suspected her elder sister, because she always stared at her with an unceasing smile.
kîtahtawê êh-nikohtêt , êkotah picikîskisîsah kâ-tah-twêhoyit . Presently, as she was gathering wood, a tomtit came and alighted here and there.

seg.gloss: “Oh, woman, I want to tell you this!

seg.q: âsay êkwah kîsihtâw kimis oskât êh-kînikikahahk , êh-wîh-wîkimisk .
seg.gloss: [no translation]
She will kill you.

p.seg: tapasî ! itik . Run away!” it told her.
sêkimik . She was frightened by these its words.

seg.gloss: “But where can I go now?”

p.seg: ôtê isi , nâtakâm , itêw . “Off here, toward the north,” it told her.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg: êkwah kêtikoskawêw wanakwaya . Then she took off her sleeves.

seg.gloss: “Now, my sleeves, gather faggots!
When you hear my elder sister calling to you, tell her ‘Wait a bit!’
Tell her, ‘I am just getting wood.’

seg.q:
kiyipa ! itikoyêko ,
cêkwah ! kîsâc mihcêt ê-wîh-nâtwâhamân , sôskwâc t-âwatâyân , itâhkêk .
seg.gloss: If she says to you, ‘Hurry!’ then, ‘Wait a bit! I want to split a lot of it first, so that I can bring it without delay,’ do you tell her.”

p.seg: êkosi nikohtêwak êkwah ôki anakwayak . Accordingly, those sleeves then gathered wood.
tapasîw êkwah aw îskwêw . The woman fled.

êkwah ,
cêskwah ! itwêyiwa . Then, “Wait a bit!” said those things.

kiyipa ! ka-matwê-itwêyit , kîtahtawê ,
nîwa ! k-êtwêyit ; “Be quick!” she was heard to call, and presently, “My spouse!” she cried;

seg.gloss: “Come back home!

p.seg: nikaskêyihtên , nîwa , êkâ mayaw êh-pê-kîwêyan , twêyiwa . I am getting sad, my spouse, because you are so long about coming home,” she said.
â , tapasîw wiya . Oh, but as for her, she fled.

piyisk ihkêyihtam awa ,
pê-kîwê , nîwah ! k-êtwêt êyak ômisimâw . Then at last elder sister grew tired of calling, “Come home, my spouse!”

seg.gloss: “Wait a bit!”
“Yah!”

p.seg:
kîtahtawê ,
ka-kisiwâhin , nîwa ! pê-kîwê ! Presently, “You will anger me, my spouse! Come home!”

seg.gloss: “Wait a bit! I first want to get some faggots.”

p.seg: piyisk pasikôw aw îskwêw , êkwah ê-nitawâpamât osîma . At last the woman arose and looked for her sister.

seg.gloss: “You actually pay no heed at all!
Now I am going to club you, my spouse!
You are taking too long about coming home!”

p.seg: êkwah pêyak pikw oskât êh-âpacihtât , itêh kâ-nikohtêyit osîma êh-itohtêt , cîki êh-ihtât , pôni-nikohtêyiwa , kotak ê-sakâyik êkotê kâw ê-matwêkahikêyit , ê-matwê-nikohtêyit . Then, using her one leg, she went to where her sister had been gathering wood, and when she got near, the other ceased chopping wood, and then, in another grove, again the other was noisily chopping and making a din at the gathering of firewood.

seg.gloss: “She keeps right on getting wood, when I call and call to her!
Now you have made me angry!

p.seg: otihtitâni , kika-pakamahotin , nîwa ! itêw osîma . When I reach you, I shall club you, my spouse!” she said to her sister.
êkwah êh-itohtêt , kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât anakwayah êh-nikohtêyit . But when she got there, presently she saw the sleeves that were gathering wood.
êkwah pahkisinwak ôki anakwayak . Then those sleeves fell to the ground.

seg.q: hâ hah , tâpwê nikisiwâhik nîwa , kâ-tapasît !
seg.gloss: “Oho, truly my spouse has angered me by running away!

p.seg: ncawâc itah atimitâni , ka-nipahitin , nîwa ! itêw , êkwah êh-ntonawât . Wherever I overtake you, I will kill you, my spouse!” she said to her, and began seeking her.
kîtahtawê kâ-mâtâhât , êkwah êh-mitihtât . Presently she found her tracks and began to trail her.
namoya misawâc ta-pîhcâw itêh cit-êtâmoyin ! itêw osîma . “In any case there will be no distance great enough for you to flee!” she called to her sister.

ah-pa-pimâmot aw îskwêw , êkwah kisiwâk êh-pêy-ihtâyit omisah ,
hê êy ! tântêh ôyâ nimosôm ! itêw . Oh, she was swift, even though she had only one leg. Presently, as that woman fled, and her elder sister came nearer and nearer, “Alas! Where is that grandfather of mine who once was here!” she cried.
itah êh-at-ispahtât , kâ-pê-matâwisiyit wâkayôsah . In the direction in which she was running, a bear appeared in the path.

seg.gloss: “Alas, grandfather, try to save my life!
My elder sister means to kill me.”

seg.q: hê hê hê ê ha ha , nôsisê , nîstah ni , nikostâw kimis !
seg.gloss: “Dear me, dear me, dear me, my grandchild, I too am afraid of your sister!
Of manitou nature is your sister.
At any rate, flee straight ahead in this direction.”

p.seg: hâ , êkosi tapasîw aw îskwêw . Accordingly, the woman fled.
hah , kiyipa ka-pê-sâkêwêt aw îskwêw . Oh, quickly that woman came into sight.
nêy , iskôh êwakonih êh-mamisît nîwa ! itwêw , êh-otihtât ; “Fie, my spouse has come down to depending on this creature!” she cried, when she came to him;

seg.gloss: “Bear, where is my spouse!”

p.seg: tâniwâtokê ! itêw . “I do not know where she is!” he told her.

seg.q: nama cî kikâtâw nîwa ? kiyipah wîhtamawin !
seg.gloss: “Are you not hiding my spouse? Quick, tell me!”
“I do not know anything about her.”
“Quick. No doubt you are hiding her from me.
I am ready to kill you.”

p.seg: âta wîh-kisiwâsiw wâkayôs ; mâka namoya nântaw kîh-tôtam . The bear was getting into a rage, but he could do nothing.
êyak ômô ohci kâ-kîskâyik oskât , êyak ôhci tah-tahkiskawêw ôhi wâkayâsah ; nipahêw . With her cut-off leg she kicked the bear; she killed him.
âhci pikw êkotah ntonikêw . She kept up the search in that place.
kwah mina micihcipayîstawêw , kîtahtawê mîn êkwah kisiwâk êh-atiy-askôwât . again she set out on her trail, and presently again she was close upon the other's heels.
hêy , tântêh ôyâ nimosôm ? itêw , pôt êwakoni misi-pisiwa . “Alas, where is my grandfather who once was here!” she said to one, and he turned out to be a Great Lynx.

mîn iyikohk awa êyâta-takohtêt ,
hê êy ! iskôh êwakoni âta êh-mamisît nîwa ! itêw , ê-nêsôwisit , êh-takohtêt ; And when that person arrived there, “Ha, my spouse has come down to placing vain hope even in this creature!” she cried to him, weary, as she arrived;

seg.gloss: “Great Lynx, where is my spouse?”
“Why, where can she be?”
“Surely you are hiding her from me!
Quick tell me where you are hiding my wife.
I am quite ready to kill you!”
“I know nothing about her.”
“Quick, I tell you! Tell me about my spouse!”

p.seg: pisinê ê-wîh-kitotât , âsay kâ-tahkiskawât ; nipahêw . Before he could speak to her, she had already kicked him; she killed him.
tâpiskôc ayisk êh-pâskiswât , êy-isi-sôhkêpayiyik oma oskât aw ômisimâw . For it was just as if she had shot him, so powerful was that elder sister's leg.
êkwah ê-kîh-nipahât , êkwah mina nitonam itah êh-pimohtêyit osîma . And when she had killed him, then again she looked for where her sister had gone.
tâpwê mîna mâtâhêw . Again she found her trail, [sic]
êkwah mina mitihtêw . and again she tracked her.
kîtahtawê mîn êkwah kisiwâk êkwah iskôwêw . And presently she was following close upon her.

kîtahtawêh ômis îtwêw :
hê êy ! tâniwâhk nimosô ? itwêw . Presently she cried: “alas, where is my grandfather?”
pôtih , ê-sâkêwêpahtât , kâ-wâpamât misi-kinêpikwa . There, as she went running round a bend, he beheld a Great Serpent.

seg.gloss: “Now, my grandchild, at any rate, flee along here!

p.seg: âta wiy âni nikostâw kimis ; manitôwiw , itik . But truly I do fear your elder sister; she is of manitou nature,” he told her.

seg.gloss: “Alas, my grandfather, try to kill her!

p.seg: ê-wîh-nipahit anah nimis ! itêw . That elder sister of mine means to slay me!” she told him.
êkos êh-tapasît . She fled.
kîtahtawê êh-sâkêwêpahtât . Presently she came running into sight.

seg.gloss: “Ha, even in this creature my spouse places hope!”

p.seg: itah ôhi k-âyâyit , êkotah nakîw . Where the other was, she stopped in her course.

seg.gloss: “Great Serpent, where is my spouse!”
“Ha, I know nothing about her.”
“Tell me!
You are hiding her from me, and I am going to kick you!
I'll kill you!”

p.seg: aha , pisinê êh-waskawiyit , tahkiskawêw ; piyis nipahêw . As soon as the other budged, she kicked him; in the end she killed him.
êkosi mîna êh-ntonawât osîma . Thereupon again she sought her sister.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk itah êsah ê-kîh-pimâmoyit . Presently she saw where she had passed in flight.
êkwah mîn êyakoni mitihtêw . Then again she followed her trail.
êkwah nama kêkway ta-mamisît aw oskinîkiskwêw . Now there was nothing in which that young woman could place hope.
kîtahtawê êh-pa-pimipahtât , kâ-wâpahtahk sâkahikan êh-âhkwatiniyik , kâ-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwah êkotah tâwakâm . Presently, as she ran on and on, she saw a frozen lake and a man at the centre of it.
êyakonih êkwah môskîstawêw . She ran toward him.

êh-otihtât , awîn ôhi , pêyakokâtêyiwa , êh-misikitiyit asiniya êh-nayômâyit , êh-cîkahwâyit miskwamiya , êh-êskêyit . When she reached him, why, he was one-legged, and was carrying a huge stone, and pounding the ice to make holes in it.

seg.gloss: “Alas, grandfather mine, try to save me; my sister means to kill me!

p.seg: pimâcihiyini , ahpôh ici kika-wîkimitin , itêw . If you save my life, I am willing to marry you,” she said to him.
namwâc kitâpamik ahpôh ; namoya kitotik . He did not even look at her; he did not speak to her.

seg.q: hê êy , ahpôh ici kik-ôyôhtâwîmitin , pimâcihiyini !
seg.gloss: “Alas, alas, if you like, I will even take you as my father, if you save my life!”

p.seg: namwâc ahpôh wîh-ka-kitâpamik . He would not even glance at her.
êkwah kaskêyihtam , kisiwâk êkwah êh-pêy-ayâyit omisah . She was in distress, for her sister was now coming near.

seg.gloss: “Alas, quickly try to save me, for a manitou means to kill me!”

p.seg: êkoyikohk kâ-kitâpamikot . Only then did he look at her.

seg.gloss: “That is no manitou.

p.seg: kimis ana , itik . Tbat is your elder sister,” he told her.

seg.gloss: “Yes, but she means to kill me!
Try to save my life.

p.seg: ahpôh ici kik-ôstêsimitin , itêw . I am even willing to take you as my elder brother,” she told him.

seg.gloss: “Yes!”

p.seg: êkwah miywêyihtam awa pêyakokât . Now that One-Leg was pleased.

ôtah , itêw ,
ôtah pimipahtâh ! “Here,” he told her, “run along here!”

tâpwê êkotah ati-pimohtêw tastawayakap . So she went along there, passing through between his legs. LB on {tastawayakap}: The only meaning I could obtain, “between the legs” does not fit One-Leg. If it is correct, the narrator has gone astray.

seg.gloss: “Keep walking along that little path there.
When you reach the main trail on the shore, you will see a little wooden house.

p.seg: êkotah takohtêyani , êkotah pîhtokêhkan , nisîm , itêw êkwah . When you reach it, then do you enter it, my little sister,” he told her now.
â , miywêyihtam aw oskinîkiskwêw . Oh, the young woman was glad.
tâpwê ati-sipwêpahtâw êkwah . And so she ran away.
ayis êkwah pêtisâpamêw omisah . For even now she saw her elder sister approaching.

tâpwê êh-ati-kapât om ê-sakâyik , êh-matâwisit , kâ-wâpahtahk wâskahikanis mitoni ê-miywâsiniyik . Really, when on her way she came to the shore where were those woods, and came upon the trail, she saw a little wooden house, a very good one.
êkotah pîhtokêw . She entered it.
êkwah awa otihtêw wîci-pêyakokâtah . That other one came to her fellow one-leg.
pêyakokât , tâniwâ nîwa ? itêw . “One-Leg, where is my spouse?”
tâpiskôc êkâ nânitaw êh-itât , âhci pikoh êh-êskêyit . As though she had said nothing at all to him, he kept on breaking the ice.

seg.gloss: “It is to you I am saying this, One-Leg!

seg.q: kanik ôt âw an êkâ wîh-kitâpamit !
seg.gloss: Truly he does not even mean to look at me!
seg.note: LB on {kanik ôt âw an}: Expression unfamiliar to me, or error of notation; the word division is a guess.

seg.gloss: Where is my spouse!
It is you I am asking this!

p.seg: kêka ka-nipahitin , êkâ kâ-wê-kâ-kitosiyin ! itêw . I am ready to kill you, since you do not care to talk to me!” she told him.

âhci pikoh ta-cîkahikêyiwa , nanâtohk êh-itât ,
nka-kakwê-wîhtamâk , êh-itêyihtah . He kept on pounding away, while she spoke to him in all manner of ways, thinking, “I will make him tell me.”

kîtahtawê ,
yahô , k-êtwêwitahk awa ! Presently, “Oho, the noise this person makes!

seg.gloss: She is not your spouse; she is your sister!

seg.q:
namoya ôma kiya nâpêw ; kiy ôm îskwêw ,
nîwa , k-êtwêyin !
seg.gloss: You are not a man; you are a woman, who go saying, ‘my wife’!”

p.seg: namoya ! itwêw aw îskwêw ; “No!” cried that woman;

seg.q: kiyipah kiyâm wîhtamawin : tâniwâ nîwa ? tântah kah-at-îtohtêt ?
seg.gloss: “Quickly now tell me: where is my spouse? Where has she gone from here?”

p.seg: ôtah , itêw . “Right here,” he said to her.

seg.gloss: “Where?”

p.seg: ôtah , itêw . “Right here,” he told her.

seg.gloss: “But where, One-Leg? Quick, tell me!”

p.seg: ôtah tastawayakap êh-wîh-ati-sîpâsit , ôhi kâ-nayômâyit asiniyah pakiciwêpinêyiwa . When she made to go under between his legs, he dropped the stone which he was carrying.
mitoni kîskiskôhik âpihtôsiyaw ; nipahik êwakoni . It fell on her and cut her straight through at the middle; it killed her. CHECK kîskiskôhik
âhci pikw âwa ca-cîkahikêw . The man went right on pounding.
kîtahtawê êkoyikohk kiskisiw êkwah ôh iskwêwa ; kîwêw . Presently at last he remembered that woman; he went home.
êkwah êh-takohtêt owâskahikanisihk , awîn ôhi , kîh-apiyiwa osîma . When he arrived at his little wooden house, there sat his little sister.
êkwah nama kêkway titâ-mîciyit . But there was nothing for her to eat.
hâw , mihcêt wâpamêw pîhtatwânah êh-akociniyit aw îskwêw . She saw a great many quivers hanging there.
ay-apiw awa pêyakokât . One-Leg stayed there.

yahô , êkâ kêkway nisîm ntasamâh , k-êtapiyân ! itwêyiwa , êy-otinamiyit kicôhcikanis , êh-miyâhkasamiyit , êkwah ê-yôhtênamiyit . “Ho, here I am sitting like this, and have not give my little sister anything to eat!” he said, and took a little flute, and burned incense under it, and opened the door.
ê-kitohtât , kiyipa mostoswah kâ-pâpayiyit . When he played on the flute, quickly the buffalo came running.
êyakoni pâh-pimwêw . He shot them with arrows.
iyikohk êh-mêstinahk pêyak ôma opîhtatwâna , êkoyikohk pôyôw . When he had used up one of his quivers, he ceased.
tapisiyiwa kahkiyaw mostoswah . All the buffalo ran away.
hâ , nisîm , nîpisisah kahkiyaw ntaw-ôtinah , itêw . “Now, little sister, go take up all my arrows,” he told her.
êkosi wayawîw aw ôskinîkiskwêw , êh-otinahk acosisah . So the young woman went out and took up the arrows.

êkwah ,
hâ , nisîm , kahkiyaw otêyaniya pikoh otinah , itêw osîma , Then, “Now, little sister, take all their tongues, but nothing more,” he told his sister,

tâpwê aw îskwêw ê-kîh-otinahk môhkomân , êh-ntawi-manisahk otêyaniyah piko , kahkiyaw êh-otinahk , êkwah ê-pîhtokêt , êkwah otêyaniyah êh-kîsisahk , êh-paminawasot . and so the woman, taking a knife, went and cut only the tongues; she took them all and came in, and cooked the tongues, preparing a meal.

êkwah aw ôskinîkiskwêw êh-wayawît , ê-wîh-pônahk , ôhi mihcêt kâ-nipahâyit ostêsah namwâc kêkway pimisiniyiwa . But when the young woman went out to get fuel, none at all lay there of the many beasts her brother had killed.
mâmaskâtam , mihcêt ê-kîh-nipahâcik mostoswah . She was amazed, for they had killed many buffalo.
êkosi êkwah ê-kîh-mîcisocik , êkwah awa nâpêw otinam manitôwêkin , kêkway êh-ati-miyât ôh ôsîma . When, then, they had eaten, the man took some black stroud and gave it to his sister.
haw , nsîm , osîhtâh kitayôwinisah , itêw ; “There, little sister, make clothes for yourself,” he told her;

seg.q: niya pisisik nitatoskân miskwamîhk , tahkih êh-êskêyân .
seg.gloss: “I am always working at the ice, making holes.

p.seg: êkâya wîhkâc , - kîtahtawê awiyak ôtah ta-takosin , nisîm , - kâya wîhkâc tawinamaw awiyak , piyêyakoyini , itêw . Do you never for at some time someone will come here, little sister do you never open the door for anyone, when you are alone,” he told her.
tâpwê ka kâh-kaskikwâtisôw aw ôskinîkiskwêw , êkwah êh-miyohot , êh-nânapâcihot . So then that young woman kept sewing for herself, and then dressed in good clothes and decked herself out. CHECK ka
êkwah miyosiw . Then she was handsome.
têkohtêci awa pêyakokât , miywêyihtam êh-kwayâcih-paminawasoyit osîma . Whenever One-Leg came home, he was glad, becuase his sister had already done the cooking.
êkotah ohci mistahi kitimâkêyimêw ôh ôsîma . Therefore, he became very fond of his sister.
nama wîhkâc wayawîtimihk kêkway nâtamiyiwa , ât êh-pêyakokâtêt . She never had to fetch anything out of doors, even though he was one-legged.

iyikohk kêtâtwâwi otêyiniya ,
hâw , nisîm , nânapâcihoh ; wawêsî , êh-itât , Whenever they had eaten up the tongues, “Now, little sister, deck yourself out; put on your finery,” he would tell her;

kîsi-wawêsiyici , êh-miyâhkasahk okicôhcikanis ,
hâw , ispimihk akosî ôtah waskahikanisihk , itêw ; and, when she had put on her finery, and he had burned incense under his flute, “Now climb up on the roof of the house,” he would tell her;

pâpayitwâwi mostoswak , iyikohk kahkiyaw sipwêpayitwâwi , tapasîtwâwi , ka-nîhtakosîn , itêw osîma . “When the buffalo come, then only after all of them have gone away, after they have fled, only then you are to climb down,” he told his little sister.
êkosi miyâhkasam okicohcikanis . Then he held his flute in the incense smoke.
â , kihcêkosîw aw oskinîkiskwêw . The young woman climbed aloft.

êkwah wiya pêyakokât êh-kîsi-yôhtênahk , kitohtâyiwa , kâ-pâpahtâyit mostoswah , êh-waskâpayiyit wîkiwâw ôma . Then, when One-Leg had opened the door, she blew the flute, and the buffalo came running, circling round their dwelling.

êkwah awa pêyakokât êh-nôcihât iyikohk , êkoyikohk ê-tapasiyit , êkoyikohk nîhtakosîw aw oskinîkiskwêw . Then, when One-Leg made war on them, and after they had fled, then the young woman climbed down.

ê-kîh-akotât kicohcikanis ,
nhâw , nsîmis , nîpisisah ntaw-ôtinah , itêw . After hanging up the little flute, “Now, sister, go take up my arrows,” he told her.
wayawîw , ê-ntaw-ôtinahk acosisah . She went out and took up the arrows.

êh-kîh-pîhtokatât ,
pisisik otêyaniya otina , nisîm ; wiyâs wiya namoya . When she had brought them in, “Take nothing but tongues, little sister; but not the meat.

tahtwâw mênahoyâni , têyaniyah piko kit-ômîciwiniyin , êy-isi-takahkêyimitân , nisîm , itêw ; Whenever I kill game, you shall have only the tongues for your food, so highly do I esteem you, little sister,” he said to her;

ê-kîh-kitimâkisiyin ,
mahtih nka-kitimâkêyimâw nisîm ! k-êtêyihtamân , itêw . “When you were in piteous straits, ‘Let me befriend my little sister!’ was my thought,” he told her.
êkosi ntaw-ôtinam pisisik otêyaniyah . Acordingly, she went and took only the tongues.
êkwah êkotah ayâwak . So there they dwelt.

seg.gloss: “Little sister, never go out of doors.
Even though you see somebody, even though somebody comes here, you are not to go out of doors.

p.seg: mihcêtiwak ayîsiyiniwak êkâ katawa êh-itâtsicik , itêw . There are many persons of evil ways of life,” he told her.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg: tâpwê kâ-kapê-kîsik pêyakôw aw îskwêw , wiya awa pêyakokât pisisik êh-ntaw-êskêt miskwamîhk . So daily all day long the woman stayed alone, while One-Leg always went to chop holes out on the ice.

kiyîsi-nânapâcihoyit ,

tâpwê kêtohtâyici , mostoswah pâpayiwa , ê-waskâpayit wîkiwâhk , êh-nôcihât pêyakokât . Truly, whenever she sounded it, the buffalo came, and circled round thier house, while One-Leg attacked them. ? e-wâskâpayiyit

êkosi ay-ayâwak , wiy âwa tahto-kîsikâw miskwamîhk êh-atoskêt awa pêyakokât . In this way they dwelt there, and as for One-Leg, he worked every day on the ice.
kîtahtawê kiskêyihtam pêyakokât ê-wîh-takosiniyit awiya . Then at one time One-Leg knew that someone would come there.

ômis îtêw osîma :
nisîmis , wîh-takohtêw wîsahkêcâhk . Thus he spoke to his sister: “Little sister, Wisahketchahk will come here. LB: The whole motif, beginning where One-Leg befriends the young woman, occurs in a Menomini story, in which, however, the mischief-maker is not the Culture Hero, but the rabbit, and “prairie-weeds were his arrows.” Three facts seem relevant, though I do not know in what relation they stand: (1) the story is not a typical Culture Hero tale, but one of the few in which he appears as a secondary character; (2) in general the Culture Here plays a more important part in Menomini thought and story than in Cree; (3) his name in Menomini is {me'napus}: “Big-Rabbit,” which may be an adaptation of Ojibwa {nânabuc} (Cree, easter {nânapus}, or of some earlier Memomini form.

seg.gloss: Do not open the door to him.
It is no good he has in mind.

osâm mistahi misiwê pêhtâkaniwiw êh-kitimâkêyimitân ,

‘Let her try to come for water!’ he says to you.”

êkosi êkwah sôhkih pimipahtâwak osîma . So then he and his sister ran fast.

â , nisîm , kitakohp wêpinah ! itêw . “Oh, little sister, throw down your blanket-robe!” he said to her.

êh-wîh-atimikocik , mîna otâsah wêpinam . When they were again about to overtake them, she threw off her leggings.
mîn êyakoni otamiwiyiwa . Over these too the creatures delayed.

mwêhcy êkwah mîna ê-wîh-atimikocik ,
â , nisîm , êkwah kipakwahtêhon wêpinah ! itêw . Then, as the creatures were again about to overtake them, “Oh, little sister, now throw your belt!” he told her.
min êyakô wêpinam . She threw it too.
wâwîs êwakô kiyipah kitâyiwa . This they devoured all the more quickly.
kiyipah êkwah wîh-atimikwak . Very soon they were now close to overtaking them.

êkwah kisiwâk êkwah wîkiwâw êh-ayâyik ,
hâ , nisîm , êyiwêhk mahtih êkwah kiskotâkay wêpinah ! itêw . Then, when their dwelling was already near, “Oh, little sister, now do you throw your dress!” he told her.
wêpinam aw ôskinîkiskwêw . The young woman cast it off.
êwako mîna mayaw êh-otihtahkik ôki mostoswak , êwako mîna otamiyiwak . As soon as the buffalo came to it, over it, too, they delayed.
êkoyikohk êkwah mitoni cîk êkwah ayâwak wîkiwâhk . But by this time they were very near to their house.
êyikohk êh-kitâcik , êkoyikohk mina sipwêpayiwak . Only when they had eaten up the dress, did they start out again.
êkoyikohk êkwah otihtam wîkiwâw . But by this time he had reached their house.
kîhcêkosîwêpinêw osîma ; êkwah wiya wîstah kîhcêkosîpayihôw . He threw his little sister to the roof; then he too flung himself up there.
âsay êkotah takopayiwah . Already the creatures arrived on the run.
kêkâc kêsiskâk , iyikohk êh-askôkocik . They nearly got there at the same time with him, so closely were they upon their heels.

êkwah êh-otinahk wîpisisah , êkwah êh-nôcihât ôhi mostoswah , miyêstinahki , kotakah êh-otinât opîhtatwâna , piyisk miton îskwahêw mostoswah . Then he took his arrows and made fight upon those buffalo, and when he had used them up, he would take another quiver, until at last he killed a great many of those buffalo.
nama mayaw kîh-nipahêw ôhi ka-wâpiskisiyit mostoswah . He had not yet succeedeed in killing the white buffalo.
kîtahtawê êkwah kâ-pikwastahwât , tâpiskôc êkwah mistahi ê-maskawisiyit . But presently he woulded it, but it seemed to be as strong as ever.

ômis îtik ;
pêyakokât , kisâkôcihin . It said to him, “One-Leg, you have defeated me.

seg.gloss: Come throw me toward the place of noon.
Off in the future mortal men will grow into life.

p.seg: âpihtâ-kîsikâhk wâpiski-mostos êy-ôtaskêt nikitimâkêyimik , itwêci , ta-tâpwêw , itik . When one says, ‘The White Buffalo that dwells in the place of noon has taken pity on me,’ he will speak true,” it said to him.
hâ , wâpiski-mostos , isi-kawipayihoh ! itêw . “Very well, White Buffalo, throw yourself hither!” he said to it.
tâpwê êkotê isi-kawipayihoyiwa . Truly, to that place it flung itself.

seg.gloss: “Ha, leave One-Leg alone!
He will exterminate us.

p.seg: piyisk sâsay kôkimâminawa sâkôcihêw ! itwêyiwa ; He has now defeated our chieftain!” they cried;

seg.gloss: “Leave him alone!”

p.seg: tâpwê nanânis âh-isi-sipwêhtêyiwa . And so in every direction they went away from there.
êkwah nîhtakosîwak osîma . Then he and his sister descended.

êkwah êh-postayôwinisêyit osîma ,
mitoni nanâpâcihoh , nisîm ! itêw . Then when his sister had donned her clothes, “Put on your best finery, little sister!” he told her.
tâpwê nanâpâcihôw . Truly she decked herself out.

mitoni êh-kîsi-wawêsît ,
hâw , wayawîtân , nisîm ! itêw . When she had put on all her ornaments, “Come, let us go out of doors, little sister!” he said to her.

ê-kîh-wayawîcik ,
â , nisîm , namoy ês âni kinwêsk êh-kîh-miyo-wîcêtân . And when they were outside, “Now little sister, it appears that I should not long be able to stay happily with you.

seg.gloss: Too much always would I be assailed and troubled for your sake.
In the end someone would destroy you.
I am too fond of you.

seg.q: cêskwah ayîsiyinwak kâ-wîh-ihtâcik itah askîhk , ôtah êh-âpihtawitâkosik k-ôtaskîn .
seg.gloss: After a time when mortal men come into being here on earth, then there in the place of the afternoon sun you will dwell.

seg.q: pêh-pêyak ayîsiyiniw kika-kitimâkêyimâw , ôki cêskwah kâ-wih-ôhpikicik ayîsiyiniwak .
seg.gloss: One and another mortal you will pity and befriend, of the mortals who in time are to grow forth.
And I shall dwell in the land of the sunset.

seg.q:
ayîsiyiniw kîhkîhk pêyak ,
nikitimâkêyimik êh-pêyakokâtêt ! itwêci , ta-tâpwêw .
seg.gloss: If in the course of time some mortal man says, ‘The One-Legged has taken pity on me,’ he will speak the truth.

p.seg:
ha , nsîm , pêskis êkotêh ôhci ê-wih-kanawêyimitân , itêw ; My little sister, at the same time from there I shall guard you,” he told her;
niyâ , nisîm , sipwêhtê ! itêw , wîst ê-sipwêhtêt , nîsôyak êh-ntaw-ôtaskîcik . “My little sister, depart!” he said to her, as he too departed, and they went to dwell in two places.
êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of the sacred story.
